isis.stitle: TSI 92-12-05 - Inspection Procedure For Verification Of Oil Or Coolant Leakage From Cylinder Head Gasket (7.3L Diesel Engine)

subjectgroup.subject: Inspection Procedure For Verification Of Oil Or Coolant Leakage From Cylinder Head Gasket (7.3L Diesel Engine)

geninfo.para: This TSI describes a systematic inspection procedure that is to be performed to alleviate unnecessary replacement of the cylinder head gasket due to misdiagnosed causes such as external oil, coolant or combustion gas leakage.

Any fluids that are leaked or spilled on the front or top of the engine have a tendency to collect in the crankcase/cylinder head gasket joint area and subsequently result in no-fault cylinder head gasket replacement.
Typically fluids light enough in viscosity run freely and appear to be leaking from the front or rear corners of the crankcase/cylinder head joint area.

Fluids of heavier viscosity sometimes remain in the crankcase/cylinder head joint area and either type of fluid can saturate the head gasket body material. These fluids during normal engine operation/vibration and thermal induced motion cause small bubbles to form which expand and collapse at varying frequency depending on engine speed. (Refer to
BLOWING BUBBLES BETWEEN HEAD AND BLOCK
of this bulletin for description of causes.)

svcproc.title: INSPECTION PROCEDURE
svcproc.para: Visually inspect engine for leaks at coolant hoses, power steering hoses, injection pump, high/low pressure fuel lines and all cover/gasket areas that seal fluids or coolant.
Inspect drain pan plug at rear of intake manifold valley pan to verify it is open. A clogged plug allows fluids to accumulate in vee of engine and eventually spill over at the rear of the engine.
Closely inspect the following areas that contribute to coolant leaks on the engine: (Refer to Figure 1, Figure 2 and Figure 3.)

item.para: Upper radiator hose at thermostat housing and top tank
Thermostat housing mounting gasket
Heater supply hose at right front cylinder head
Heater return hose at water pump housing
Coolant fill line hose at coolant inlet
Deaeration tank
Deaeration hose of air compressor coolant supply line left front of crankcase
At coolant sensors mounted in cylinder head
Water pump
Any unused pipe plug locations on cylinder heads and water pump housing
Cup plugs in ends of cylinder heads.

svcproc.para: Closely inspect the following areas that contribute to oil seepage/leakage on engine: (Refer to Figure 4, Figure 5 and Figure 6.)

item.para: Valve cover gaskets
Oil pressure gauge supply line and/or sender
Inspection pump drive gear/access cover
Low oil pressure warning switch and piping
Intake manifold valley pan to crankcase mounting front and rear
Power steering pump reservoir and/or hoses
Air compressor mounting gasket
Air compressor oil drain quad seal ring on cylinder head
Air compressor oil supply line
1/8 inch Allen head pipe plugs that intersect with oil drain holes in cylinder heads
C.D.R. valve and/or hoses
Clogged/restricted valley pan drain plug
Spillage of oil, fuel and other fluids during normal service intervals.

note.para: Returned material analysis as well as on-site investigations has indicated that head gaskets are being inadvertently replaced due to leaks at the aforementioned locations.

Since the head gasket is very seldom the cause of leak concerns, it is recommended that a thorough cleaning of the engine and/or suspected area should be performed in order to ascertain the location and/or cause of the concern prior to any head gasket replacement.

svcproc.title: BLOWING BUBBLES BETWEEN HEAD AND BLOCK
svcproc.para: The cause of these bubbles has been identified as engine oil, diesel fuel, power steering fluid and glycol/antifreeze. Any spillage or leakage of these fluids on the engine will drain along the head gasket joint and will be trapped at the edge of the gasket material. On a cold engine, the bubbles may not be evident. During engine operation small soap-like bubbles develop and burst due to heat and joint motion. The higher the engine speed the more rapid this bubbling occurs.
This phenomenon is caused by joint motion between cylinder head and crankcase and requires an external source of fluids.
Engineering testing and examination of these gaskets reveals that no combustion gases have escaped the combustion seals of these gaskets.
